executive_summary: Volatile input prices and numerous diverse shifts in consumer tastes have challenged bread producers, but declining revenue has not been baked into performance. Producers have adjusted their product mix to align with changing consumer preferences and decreased sales volumes in key product segments.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Fluctuating Input Prices Remain a Staple
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wheat and other key inputs, such as sugar and dairy, have exhibited significant price fluctuations in global commodity markets. Wheat prices spiked 28.1% in 2018 and, after a decline in 2019, were followed by double-digit growth in 2020, another double-digit spike of 43.3% in 2021 and 35.5% in 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consumer Tastes Shift Due to Healthier Lifestyles
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Bread producers have been negatively impacted by dietary trends and growing health concerns, encouraging many households to avoid the high levels of carbohydrates naturally found in bread products. In response to the demands of an increasingly health-conscious public, bread producers have developed new, more nutritious varieties of sliced sandwich bread, pastries and cakes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer Preferences Drive Changes in Production
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Healthy eating trends will continue to drive bakeries to produce items, such as flaxseed-topped loaves, multigrain rolls and ancient-grain bagels, that command a higher price than traditional types of bread. As a result, sales for white loaf bread, dinner rolls and private-label bread products will decline as consumers' demand for specialty bread grows.
America's diverse and ever-changing palate, especially for pita, naan and other ethnic flatbreads, will encourage a diversification of product lines by the industry's mass-market and niche producers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ECONOMIC GROWTH ENCOURAGES PREMIUM PURCHASES AS COMPETITION CHALLENGES PROFITABILITY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increasing disposable income levels will push consumers to choose more premium and specialty varieties of bread over conventional private-label products, which are typically less expensive.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry manufacture fresh and frozen bread and other baked goods that include cakes, muffins and croissants but exclude cookies and crackers. Retail and commercial establishments then sell these products to downstream supermarkets, convenience stores and food-service providers. Many bakeries also sell their products directly to consumers.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - decreasing

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Health-conscious Americans have become bread-averse. Producers have responded by introducing healthier alternatives in frozen, fresh and even ethnic varieties.
Import competition has risen. The American palate has become more diverse, encouraging imports from countries such as Mexico.
Producers follow strict FDA guidelines on product labeling and content. Recalls and false content claims can prove ruinous for a producer's reputation.
Imports have increased as a result of trade agreements with neighboring countries in North America.
Bread varieties are consistently being reformulated. Varieties with higher levels of fiber and grain proteins are increasingly popular among consumers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment comprises stores that purchase products in bulk directly from commercial bakeries that manufacture and wholesale baked products. Most major commercial bakeries have their own distribution fleets, which are typically used to deliver bread products straight from the production facility to major retail chains. Supermarkets serve as the single most important point of purchase for end-use consumers. The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a large uptick in demand for this segment in 2020, as a widespread shutdown and coronavirus health concerns drove consumers to increase dining at home.

This market includes full-service and fast food restaurants, the hospitality industry, food service contractors and other commercial or institutional customers, such as schools, prison systems and corporate cafeterias as schools, prison systems and corporate cafeterias. Food service clients, such as restaurants, have increased demand for bread as rising discretionary income and leisure time have encouraged Americans to dine out more frequently. In 2020, COVID-19 resulted in a significant drop in demand from this segment, as widespread shutdown and concerns about the virus drove consumers to curtail dining out.

This segment includes specialty bakeries, cake shops, coffee shops and gourmet cafes. Specialty stores typically sell small or individual-sized pastries alongside other accompaniments, such as coffee or tea. Since most local bakeries bake fresh bread and other baked products, operators have attracted increasing numbers of health-conscious consumers who prefer handmade, artisan-style breads to packaged bread products available at larger grocery stores. Increases in discretionary income and consumer spending are also expected to boost demand from this market, especially from retail bakeries that produce gourmet bread varieties at a premium price.

Exports are low due to the perishable nature of bread and other baked products. However, shifting consumer preferences in Mexico, Asia and some parts of the European Union have boosted exports of specialty products, such as gluten-free and low-glycemic bread.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Bread (white, wheat, rye, etc.), including frozen
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes fresh, packaged, refrigerated and frozen loaf breads. French bread, white bread and wheat bread are common varieties of bread consumed in the United States. Artisan breads are one example of a specialty variety with steadily rising market share. The introduction of healthier bread varieties made with ingredients, such as whole grains, spelt and ancient grains, has expanded rapidly at the expense of the white loaf segment due to shifting health trends. Health-conscious Americans have increasingly preferred whole grain, multigrain or otherwise unprocessed bread products to white loaf and other processed bread products.

Fresh and frozen loaves of bread, rolls, bagels and croissants have seen products reformulated to reduce sodium, trans fats and high fructose corn syrup levels while adding higher levels of fiber and grain proteins. This trend has increased the market share of organic, all-natural or gluten-free rolls, bagels and croissants, which generally are whole wheat or multigrain varieties.

Products in the fresh dessert segment include pies, soft cakes, cupcakes, brownies and other baked sweets. While these products have many substitutes, they remain a popular and significant revenue source. Producers are expanding product lines, using healthier inputs to meet the nutritional eating preferences of some consumers. Despite growing health concerns and new diet trends, Americans are snacking more than ever, which has aided this segment's growth.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Frozen cakes, pies and other frozen desserts
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes frozen pies, soft cakes, cupcakes, brownies and other baked sweets. Price-conscious consumers are drawn to this market since products are typically less expensive than the fresh-baked alternatives. The introduction of cakes made from whole wheat flour or other healthier, unprocessed ingredients and brands that produce healthier options have aided demand for frozen products.

Other products include various retail bakery items and other commercial bakery items. Other retail bakery items include pastries not intended for dessert and other specialty items in bricks-and-mortar bakeries. Other commercial bakery items are packaged ones that typically have a longer shelf life than fresh retail goods. These can be distributed to retail outlets like convenience stores and in-store bakeries.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Wheat flour is the main ingredient in most bread products. Though bread is a staple for most Americans, fad diets and growing health concerns are causing consumers to avoid bread and carbohydrates, resulting in a weaker demand for industry products. Declines in per capita wheat flour consumption pose a potential threat to the industry.

The Healthy Eating Index measures the percentage of a recommended diet that an average American consumes. Americans are becoming increasingly aware of the nutritional value of certain food items and are avoiding foods high in fat, sugar and carbohydrates, like bread and pastries. As consumers gravitate toward healthier food choices, demand for conventional breads and baked goods decreases, reducing demand and hampering industry performance.

Per capita disposable income measures the average individual's ability to purchase discretionary goods or services. As disposable income rises, consumers can buy more bread and trade up to premium products, helping industry revenue. As disposable income falls, consumers will purchase bread products less frequently or choose to buy lower-margin varieties.

The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the US dollar against the currencies of the country's major trading partners. As the dollar appreciates, imported products become comparatively less costly in the domestic market and consumers may opt for imported products. At the same time, exports falter as they become relatively more expensive on the international market.

An increase in the price of wheat will increase industry revenue but may harm industry profitability. Operators can choose to pass on rising input costs in the form of higher product prices, but this may hurt demand if prices remain high for long periods. Conversely, when wheat prices fall, so does revenue, even as profits are eased.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The growing popularity of ethnic food varieties has exposed many US consumers to types of bread produced internationally, especially flatbreads like tortillas, pita and naan. The growing Hispanic population in the United States has contributed to the increased demand for Mexican bread products, with many being shipped directly from Mexico. Canada and Mexico account for approximately two-thirds of all bread imports to the US, with Canada's share being the largest and growing faster than that of other importing countries.

Exports are low due to the perishable nature of bread and the preferences of domestic bakeries to minimize transportation costs, rendering global trade expensive to manufacturers. Rather than export goods, many of the leading producers have opened production facilities abroad to take advantage of the growing demand for bread in foreign markets. Canada and Mexico are the most prominent destinations for domestically produced bread and account for over three-quarters of all bread producers' export revenue, with the share increasing over the years as the exports to other main export markets declined. Proximity to the United States enables bread producers to transport highly perishable bread products easily to neighboring countries. Canada's share of exports reigns supreme, at more than five times Mexico's share.

business_locations.location_description: Commercial bakeries service a variety of food service industry establishments, such as hotels, motels, restaurants and caterers, in the region. The region includes some of the country's biggest and most affluent cities, such as New York City and Philadelphia, making it very attractive for smaller bakeries, coffee shops and cafes.

Manufacturers in this region have easy access to key ingredients, as California is a major agricultural center in the United States. Moreover, this region features a large and affluent consumer base, well-established infrastructure and easy access to populous cities.

California and New York are densely populated, with a diverse population with diverse ethnic tastes. This can attract smaller and artisinal producers as well as larger producers. California's extensive agricultural sector, which produces a variety of grains, makes it a strategic location for establishments. On the other hand, New York's status as a popular tourist attraction and its renowned culinary diversity would draw in numerous smaller, distinctive bread producers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act (1990) gave the FDA authority to require nutrition labeling on most foods. Accurate nutrition labels with nutrient content claims and proper health messages or warnings for things including allergies or carcinogens apply, as well as modernization acts (FLMA 2023), propose additional labeling requirements for the food industry.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and state governments enforce policies to manage how food processors manage their waste, with the Clean Water Act (CWA) being of foremost concern. The CWA requires companies that discharge waste to have a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit.

The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) sets and regulates standards for safe and healthy working conditions. For manufacturing industries, this entails maintaining secure and up-to-date equipment for production, proper training for machine operators to avoid hazardous mishaps and providing safety apparel for workers.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Low startup costs for small producers
barriers_points.barrier_description: Many small producers rely on labor, unable to invest in equipment when starting up.
High wages and lack of skilled labor can be barriers to entry in some markets.

basis_points.basis_title: Innovation and adapting to changing preferences
basis_points.basis_description: Innovation is at the heart of commercial success. Bread producers must adapt to changing consumer preferences, introducing new varieties and healthier options.
Brand loyalty keeps consumers tied to their favorite brands. Well-known breads are associated with quality, based on taste and ingredients.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Major food producers are often more recognizable and can better leverage production scale and established distribution networks, allowing them to capture a significant market share as they have lower per-unit production costs and can provide lower-priced goods.

Many companies are local and serve a limited geographic area. Other retail bakeries produce niche products, such as handmade, artisan breads, typically not offered by larger packaged bread manufacturers. These factors lead to market fragmentation and low concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Volatile Purchase Costs Passed On Downstream
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The graph shows the percentage of revenue spent on purchases by the bread production industry from 2005 to 2023 (projected). The data points indicate that the percentage of revenue spent on purchases has been volatile, ranging from around 40% to 60% over the years.
Marketing accounts for a small share of revenue but marketing and advertising strategies strengthen customer loyalty and retention rates, especially for national brand product lines.

Labor costs have increased, impacting the smaller local bread producers with less automation and requiring substantial manual labor. Wage costs are higher than other food processing industries because bread production is relatively labor intensive.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Many small producers rely on labor, unable to invest in equipment when starting up. High wages and lack of skilled labor can be barriers to entry in some markets.

Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations. However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Income levels, the rate of inflation and the price of close substitutes will determine whether consumers choose more affordable private-label brands or premium products. Low-carbohydrate dietary fads and mainstream marketing of gluten-free foods have caused a smaller but expanding segment of consumers to limit or even eliminate bread from their diets.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Key Input Volatility Produces Revenue Swings
volatility_points.volatility_description: Food inputs like wheat flour, other grains, milk and sugar are all key inputs for bread producers. Wheat prices have been volatile, rising drastically from 2020 through 2022. The cost of ingredients fundamentally shapes the selling prices of bread and strongly influences the direction in which industry revenue will move.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The introduction of healthier bread varieties made with ingredients, such as whole grains, spelt and ancient grains, has expanded rapidly at the expense of the white loaf segment due to shifting health trends. Fresh and frozen loaves of bread, rolls, bagels and croissants have seen products reformulated to reduce sodium, trans fats and high fructose corn syrup levels while adding higher levels of fiber and grain proteins.
Producers are expanding product lines, using healthier inputs to meet the nutritional eating preferences of some consumers in the fresh dessert segment.
The introduction of cakes made from whole wheat flour or other healthier, unprocessed ingredients and brands that produce healthier options have aided demand for frozen dessert products.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for bread and related foods tend to be stable and sales of which are more dependent on disposable income levels.

FAQs.question: Does your company produce just one variety of breads or an array?
FAQs.answer: Diversified producers will exhibit lower degrees of revenue volatility, aiding profitability. Nondiversified producers will be more subject to output price fluctuations, hindering profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts with downstream customers will exhibit more stable revenue. Producers that exercise input price and supply management will have a better time planning production, boosting potential profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Producers located in proximity to key selling markets will exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Producers located in proximity to key input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Bread producers that fail to adopt the latest technologies may become uncompetitive and be forced to exit the industry. By automating inventory management and input orders, labor resources can be redirected to more efficient tasks. Labor costs can be reduced by adopting automated inventory management software. Operators leveraging the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant producers will exhibit lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. Noncompliant producers will be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Producers with a penchant for environmentally friendly and organic produce may be favored by the public. Noncompliant producers will be subject to fines and penalties, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company had any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue, enduring price declines better and protecting against profit margin volatility. Major companies have been actively acquiring competitors and their assets, increasing total cash flow.

FAQs.question: How does your profit compare with those of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Producers that adopt the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiencies. Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will exhibit lower revenue volatility and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to customers? Are you located in key markets where consumers can afford premium prices?
FAQs.answer: Successful manufacturers are able to pass on increasing input costs by raising their product prices without significantly lowering product demand.

FAQs.question: Do you have a reputation for quality? How do you promote your various product brands?
FAQs.answer: Brand recognition and popularity is critical for operators that want to expand into new channels (e.g. convenience stores, coffee shops) and obtain greater shelf space in supermarkets and grocery stores.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a reputation for good industry relations? How do you keep labor costs low while providing quality products?
FAQs.answer: Due to the moderate labor intensity and high ratio of wages to revenue, workplace efficiency is a main factor determining production speed and volume.

FAQs.answer: Though bread has been a staple for most Americans, fad diets and growing health concerns are causing consumers to avoid bread and other carbohydrates, resulting in weaker demand for industry products.

FAQs.answer: As consumers gravitate toward healthier food choices, demand for conventional breads and baked goods decreases, hampering industry performance.
